stream_context.summary: Kaze worked primarily on Course 11, the Power Plant level. The stream focused on designing and programming new platforming mechanics, most notably pivoting from a 'dangling platform' concept to a 'weight platform' system after a suggestion from Biobak. He also revealed a major performance optimization and discussed his broader game design philosophies.

development_findings.summary: A major late-stage performance optimization was achieved by changing coins from 3D billboards to 2D screen-space sprites, resulting in a 10-15% FPS gain.
development_findings.quote: We found like a 10-15% performance improvement. At this stage, that is crazy... this is done by making the coins, instead of having them be billboards, they are now rectangles in screen space.

development_findings.summary: Kaze detailed the full five-stage layout of the Power Plant level before starting to model it, showing a process of thorough pre-planning and designing the player's learning curve for new mechanics.
development_findings.quote: The vibe I want... I have all five sections here planned out and I have two rooms sketched.

development_findings.summary: The game's difficulty is benchmarked against the original Super Mario 64, but improved controls allow for challenges that may appear harder than they actually are.
development_findings.quote: About vanilla Mario 64. Although, keep in mind, the controls in this work a lot better. So a lot of stuff can be looking more difficult, while actually being easier.

development_findings.summary: Kaze expressed a preference for a cleaner, less 'noisy' visual style, contrasting his approach with the grainy textures found in some Mario Galaxy levels.
development_findings.quote: I don't like the super grainy style. It's just too noisy I guess.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a new, more transparent method for defining variables in the code to help developers avoid memory-related bugs like RAM collisions.
development_findings.quote: This is way more transparent than what the actual memory layout is... now he can actually know when you have RAM collisions.

development_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally 'hacked' the physics for the new weight platforms, adding a delay before they reset to make the mechanic more useful and satisfying for the player.
development_findings.quote: sometimes you do need to hack the physics just a little bit to make everything work

development_findings.summary: A running joke and world-building element was developed with the community, establishing that Bowser's minions formed a union and received absurdly minimal benefits, such as 'Green Koopas are allowed to turn around at edges'.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a design philosophy that prioritizes intrinsic rewards (innovative concepts, interesting mechanics) over extrinsic ones (collect-a-thons), which influences his approach to level design.
context_findings.quote: I thought Odyssey was just okay too because exploring the game just didn't feel rewarding for me. I don't like games that rely on having you find little treats. I want the game that rewards me with finding cool shit. I want to see cool concepts, not extrinsic motivation like, oh, number go up.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is developing the game in his spare time while holding a full-time job, which dictates a flexible, non-committal release schedule.
context_findings.quote: I have a full time job, I can't dedicate that much time to just working on this. You're just gonna have to wait until it's done.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentioned recently moving into a house and being 'enslaved to the bank,' reinforcing a lifelong frugal mindset that may influence his non-commercial approach to game development.
context_findings.quote: I've been living like a very poor person my whole life, so it makes no difference. The only time I ever remember buying something for fun was a stupid toy I bought when I was 5.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes frequently updated competitive games invalidate player skill over time and prefers stable, unchanging rule sets like in chess, revealing his appreciation for deep, persistent systems.
context_findings.quote: If you have a competitive game and you push frequent updates, you're just ruining it. There's no point in playing your game if your skill is just a measurement of how much you play and it's fucked up.

context_findings.summary: Kaze ended the stream early due to physical discomfort (neck pain), highlighting the physical toll of long development sessions.
context_findings.quote: My neck pain today makes this kind of uncomfortable. And I think I'm going to end stream here. I want to rest my neck.

biobak.summary: Biobak proposed changing a swinging platform concept to a weight-based system, which Kaze immediately adopted as a better and more unique mechanic.
biobak.quote: Instead of moving the platforms, what about the weight system? Standing on one moves the other one up.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a design suggestion for a boss fight (the black boss) which Kaze agreed with and planned to implement, showing Biobak's influence on gameplay design.
biobak.quote: I agree with Biobak's idea to make the soap go to the outside cages instead, though. I think that's a good change.

biobak.summary: Kaze explicitly delegates the final texture work for the Power Plant level to Biobak, indicating a clear division of labor and trust in Biobak's artistic skills.
biobak.quote: I will leave the textures to buy a bike but I will pick something for now that doesn't look completely awful at least

badub.summary: Kaze confirmed that all music in the game is custom-made for the project, implying Badub's work is comprehensive and integral to the game's unique identity.
badub.quote: all music in this game is custom so we're not reusing some other games music

zeina.summary: Kaze humorously described his new basement workspace as a place he's been 'banished' to by Zeina, offering a lighthearted glimpse into their personal dynamic.
zeina.quote: Zeina has banished me here. She said I'm not allowed to come up unless it's to grab food.

key_stories.title: The Weight Platform Pivot
key_stories.summary: Faced with a technical hurdle while implementing swinging platforms, Kaze pivoted the entire mechanic based on a real-time suggestion from artist Biobak. This led to the creation of a new weight-based platforming puzzle, showcasing the team's collaborative and agile approach to design.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze's initial idea for dangling platforms was proving technically complex to program, particularly in how the ropes would connect to a moving platform without graphical or animation issues.
key_stories.process: While Kaze was struggling with the programming logic for swinging platforms, contributor Biobak suggested abandoning the idea in favor of a weight-based system where one platform goes down as its counterpart goes up. Kaze immediately embraced the idea and spent a significant portion of the stream programming, testing, and fine-tuning the feel of this new mechanic.
key_stories.outcome: A new, more unique platforming mechanic based on weight and balance was created. This pivot solved the technical challenge and added a gameplay element the project was previously missing.
key_stories.key_quote: Honestly, that would be a really cool platforming mechanic. I think we're going with that idea, yes. I like that.

key_stories.title: The 15% Performance Miracle
key_stories.summary: Late in development, the team discovered a way to significantly improve game performance. By changing how coins are rendered, they achieved a massive 10-15% FPS boost, a critical optimization that enhances the player experience across the entire game.
key_stories.challenge: As a complex ROM hack, the game constantly pushes the N64's performance limits, risking framerate drops in visually dense areas.
key_stories.process: The team identified that rendering coins as 3D billboard objects was computationally expensive. By changing them to be 2D screen-space sprites, they drastically reduced the processing overhead without a noticeable negative impact on visuals.
key_stories.outcome: A significant 10-15% performance boost was achieved across the game, allowing many levels to run at a more consistent 60 FPS. Kaze described this as a massive, likely unrepeatable, late-stage victory.
key_stories.key_quote: We found like a 10-15% performance improvement. At this stage, that is crazy. I don't think we will ever see another performance improvement this big.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned a contributor named Mata was commissioned to rework the visuals for a factory level but is four months overdue on a task he said would take two weeks. Kaze expressed low confidence that the work would be completed.

open_questions.context: When discussing the massive performance boost from optimizing coins, Kaze noted that the next big improvement would come 'until we implement F3DX3.'

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that 'Yoshi Milkman' is providing new, custom sound effects for the game, such as the sound of walking on metal grates, to enhance immersion.
